result.markdown: --- title: 'Lab-5: Twas brillig, and the slithy toves...' subtitle: 'Tidy Data at the ~~wabe~~ MoMA' summary: 'Tidy Data at the ~~wabe~~ MoMA' date: 22/Nov/2022 date-modified: "2023-04-13" order: 50 image: featured.jpg image-alt: by John Tenniel format: html links: - icon: flask icon_pack: fas name: lab url: /labs/03-tidy/03-moma.html - icon: magic icon_pack: fas name: Intro to dplyr url: /labs/03-tidy/03a-Messing-with-Data-using-tidyverse.html --- ## {{< fa folder-open >}} Slides and Tutorials | R Tutorial | Slides | `dplyr` Tutorial | | |------------------|------------------|------------------|------------------| ## {{< iconify openmoji japanese-symbol-for-beginner >}} Introduction We meet the most important idea in R: tidy data. Once data is `tidy`, there is a great deal of insight to be obtained from it, by way of tables, graphs and explorations! We will get hands on with `dplyr`, the R-package that belongs in the `tidyverse` and is a terrific toolbox to clean, transform, reorder, and summarize your data. And we will be ready to ask Questions of our data and embark on anlayzing it. ## Readings - [R4DS `dplyr` chapter](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/transform.html) - [ModernDive `dplyr` chapter](http://moderndive.com/5-wrangling.html) - [RStudio `dplyr` Cheatsheet](https://github.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/blob/master/data-transformation.pdf)
